{{Use British English|date=May 2016}} '''Gambling in the United Kingdom''' is regulated by the [[Gambling Commission]] on behalf of the government's [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] (DCMS) under the [[Gambling Act 2005]]. This [[Act of Parliament]] significantly updated the [[United Kingdom|UK's]] [[gambling]] laws, including the introduction of a new structure of protections for children and vulnerable adults, as well as bringing the burgeoning [[Internet]] gaming sector within British regulation for the first time. ==Gambling forms== ===Bingo and casinos=== The game of [[Housie]] was popularised in the armed forces in the [[Second World War]] and brought back to Britain after the end. The [[Betting and Gaming Act 1960]] allowed commercial bingo halls to be set up, provided they were established as members-only clubs and had to get their take from membership fees and charges rather than as a percentage of the entry fees. [[File:Mecca bingo hall - geograph.org.uk - 1183990.jpg|thumb|A [[Mecca Leisure Group|Mecca]] bingo hall in Birmingham.]] Casinos had a similar history, with requirement for licensing from the [[Gaming Board of Great Britain]] and for casinos to be [[members only club]]s. The number of gaming machines in casinos was limited at 10. The Casino Club [[Port Talbot]] in Wales — believed to be Britain's first legal casino — was established in 1961 by gambling mogul [[George Alfred James]]. James opened several casino-cum-cabaret and fine dining establishments in the 1960s, including the Charlie Chester Casino and Golden Horseshoe in London and the Kingsway and Grand Casino in [[Southport]].{{cite web |url=http://livecasino.co.uk/category/live-casino-history/ |title=Live Casino History |accessdate=15 October 2015 |date= }}{{cite news |work=[[South Wales Evening Post]] |accessdate=14 March 2014 |title=Story of Port Talbot man who changed the world of gambling has been uncovered |url=http://www.southwales-eveningpost.co.uk/Story-Port-Talbot-man-changed-world-gambling/story-19956268-detail/story.html#ixzz2vw9MjNRj |date=18 October 2013 |author-first=G. |author-last=Roberts }} The [[Gaming Act 1968]] liberalised the law, paving the way for more commercial casinos. The first very popular game was [[Chemin D'affairs|Chemmy]], popularised by the [[Clermont Set|Clermont Club]], in [[London]]. The [[Gambling Act 2005]] paved the way for larger resort style [[casino]]s to be built, albeit in a controlled manner with one being built every few years until the Act is fully implemented. Many towns and cities bid to host one of these so-called "super casinos", which will be similar to those found in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]]. On 30 January 2007 [[Manchester]] was announced as the winning bid to be the location of the first super casino. On 29 March 2007, the [[House of Lords]] urged the Government to review plans for the massive super casino in Manchester. Instead it supported plans for 16 smaller casinos, including ones in [[Solihull]] and [[Wolverhampton]].{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2007/03/29/casino-bid-hit-by-lords-vote-97319-18826226 |work=[[Birmingham Mail]] |title=Casino bid hit by Lords vote |date=29 March 2007 |accessdate=14 March 2014 |last=Walker |first=Jonathon }} In 2007, then Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] said that the Government would not be proceeding with the super casino in Manchester.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1557170/Gordon-Brown-scraps-super-casinos.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |title=Gordon Brown scraps super-casinos |author1-first=Ben |author1-last=Quinn |author2-first=Graeme |author2-last=Wilson |accessdate=14 March 2014 |date=12 July 2007 }}{{cite news |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/jul/12/gambling.immigrationpolicy |date=12 July 2007 |accessdate=14 March 2014 |title=Brown U-turn over plan for supercasino}} Gaming machines are divided into a number of [[slot machine#United Kingdom|categories]], mainly depending upon the stakes and payouts involved, and whether there is an element of skill (these are known officially as AWPs or "Amusement with Prizes" machines). ===Gambling on sports=== [[File:"Ladbrokes" - geograph.org.uk - 700779.jpg|thumb|A [[Ladbrokes]] betting shop in [[Rawtenstall]], Lancashire.]] [[Sports betting|Sports gambling]] has a long history in the United Kingdom, having been controlled for many decades, and more recently relaxed. The 1960 Act legalised off-course bookmakers. Pool betting on horses is a monopoly of [[The Tote]]. There are over 1,000 betting shops located in London.{{cite news |url=https://best-betting-websites.com/bookmakers/london |first=Dzmitry|last=Arlou |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=24 October 2016 |title=Betting Shops Locator in London}} There is a large market in the United Kingdom for gambling on competitive sports at [[bookmaker]]s (betting shops) or licensed websites, particularly for [[horse racing|horse]], [[greyhound racing]] and [[association football|football]]. The last of these also has an associated form of gambling known as the [[football pools]], in which players win by correctly predicting the outcome of each week's matches. The online sports betting market in the UK is estimated to be worth £650 million which has seen a compounding annual growth rate from 2009–12 of approximately 7%. The total online gambling population in the UK is estimated at 2.1 million customers.{{cite news |url=http://www.favourit.com/en/content/uk-sports-betting-stats-mobile |first=James |last=Hudson |date=12 January 2014 |accessdate=18 January 2014 |title=UK sports betting market growth & mobile betting |work=Favourit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160501195258/http://www.favourit.com/en/content/uk-sports-betting-stats-mobile |archivedate=2016-05-01}} Sports gambling is advertized on television at times when children and young people are watching. There are calls for the government to control this. Dr Heather Wardle, a gambling behaviour expert from the [[London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine]], said, “It’s hard to prove what harm is being done because it’s a generational thing and the harm comes much further down the line. We’re creating the conditions that normalise gambling for a generation.”[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/aug/10/uk-government-should-restrict-gambling-ads-seen-by-children-industry-says State should restrict gambling ads seen by children, industry says] ''[[The Guardian]]'' Simon Stevens of the [[National Health Service|NHS]], expressed disapproval of eight betting firms because they do not pay towards NHS costs in countering gambling addiction.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/nov/04/bishop-attacks-delay-fixed-odds-betting-cap Bishop warns ministers over delay to £2 fixed-odds betting cap] ''[[The Observer]]'' ===Lotteries=== A statute of 1698 provided that in England lotteries were by default illegal unless specifically authorised by statute. The aim of the statute was that before the era of mass and efficient communications, those running national lotteries could claim to one part of the country that the winner lived in another, and do the same the other way: thus taking all the stakes and paying nothing out. A 1934 Act legalised small lotteries, which was further liberalised in 1956 and 1976, but even then severely limited in the stakes, and the geographical scope that they could cover, so there could be no chance of the lottery organisers deceiving the bettors. There could be no big national lottery until the Government established one, however. Other countrywide lotteries do exist, but work by dividing the prizes and stakes strictly on a geographical basis into small areas and thus technically not becoming a national lottery. The Gambling Commission called the Health Lottery in 2010 "a very fine line" and insisted it would only be legal if split into at least 31 separate, identifiable schemes so as not to become "a ''[[de facto]]'' National Lottery".{{cite web|url=http://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/90142/response/228239/attach/html/4/Health%20Lottery%20decision%20sheet.pdf.html|title=Decision of the Regulatory Panel Following a Hearing|date=2 September 2010|accessdate=14 March 2014}} ====National Lottery==== {{main article|National Lottery (United Kingdom)}} The United Kingdom's state-franchised [[lottery]] is known as the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]], which was set up under government licence in 1993. Several games are run under this brand, including '''Lotto''' and '''Thunderball'''. As with other lotteries players choose a set of numbers, say 6 from 50, with six numbers then being drawn at random. Players win cash prizes depending on how many numbers they match. The National Lottery launched a [[Europe|pan-European]] "super-lottery", called [[EuroMillions]], in 2004. Currently this is available in nine countries. [[File:EuroMillions tickets.jpg|thumb|EuroMillions tickets.]] In the United Kingdom, the national lottery has so far raised several billions of pounds for [[Big Lottery Fund|Good Causes]], a programme which distributes money via grants. 28% of lottery revenue goes towards the fund, along with all unclaimed prizes. Additionally, 12% goes to the state. The prize fund is 45% of revenue, with the remaining 15% going towards running costs and profits for the lottery organisers and ticket sellers. The odds of specific combinations occurring in the United Kingdom national lottery are as follows{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}}: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" align="center" ! Combinations ! Odds ! Allocation of winnings |- |align=center|6 numbers |1 : 13,983,816
|52% of remaining prize fund |- |align=center|5 numbers and the bonus ball |1 : 2,330,636
|16% of remaining prize fund |- |align=center|5 numbers |1 : 54,201
|10% of remaining prize fund |- |align=center|4 numbers |1 : 1,032
|22% of remaining prize fund |- |align=center|3 numbers |1 : 57
| £25 |- |align=center|2 numbers |1 : 8
|Free Lucky Dip |- |align=center|1 number |1 : 2 |No win |} ====Health Lottery==== {{main article|The Health Lottery}} In February 2011 the media tycoon [[Richard Desmond]] announced the launch of a new [http://healthlottery.org/ Health Lottery],{{cite web|url=http://www.healthlottery.co.uk/|title=The Health Lottery|accessdate=14 July 2013}} with the aim of raising a minimum of £50 million each year for health-related charities. Tickets cost £1 each and 20p in the pound goes to the charities involved.{{cite web|url=http://www.healthlottery.co.uk/lottery-good-causes|title=The Health Lottery {{!!}} Lottery Good Causes|accessdate=14 July 2013}} ====Postcode Lottery==== {{main article|UK Postcode Lottery}} The UK Postcode Lottery is in aid of charity, and works by using an entrant's postcode plus a unique three-digit number as their ticket number. Prizes are drawn every Thursday. ===Scratchcards=== [[Scratchcard]]s are a very popular form of gambling in the United Kingdom, due to their easy availability and cheap price. These are small pieces of card where an area has been covered by a substance that cannot be seen through, but can be scratched off. Under this area are concealed the items/pictures that must be 'found' in order to win. ===Amusement arcades=== The Gambling Commission identifies 3 types of [[amusement arcade]]s *adult gaming centres (AGCs) *licensed family entertainment centres (FECs) *unlicensed FECs. In 2009/2010 the FECs made up 81% of the arcade sector in gross gambling yield.[http://www.gamblingcommission.gov.uk/pdf/Gambling%20Industry%20Statistics%202009%202010%20WEB%20-%20January%202011.pdf Gambling Industry statistics 2009/2010] ===Gambling in other venues=== ====Remote gambling==== Until the [[Betting Gaming and Lotteries Act 1960]] off-course betting in person was illegal, but bets by telephone were legal since this was not considered, by the letter of the law, "resorting to a house kept for the purpose of betting".{{cite book|date=1935|page=333|title=[[Uncommon Law]]|author-first=A. P.|author-last=Herbert|authorlink=A. P. Herbert|chapter=The Postmaster-General vs. Slot. The Bookmaker's Telephone|publisher=Methuen Publishing|edition=1st}} However, it was frequent for "bookie's runners" to take and run bets from a [[Payphone|public telephone]] to the bookmaker himself. Remote gambling is growing in popularity in the United Kingdom. According to the survey conducted by the Gambling Commission, as of March 2010, 10.7% of the 8,000 adults surveyed said they had participated in at least one form of remote gambling in the previous 4 weeks. In 2009 the figure was 10.5%, in 2008 – 7.2%, in 2007 – 8.8%, in 2006 – 7.2%. The major part of these gamblers was represented by those playing the National Lottery online. Upon their exclusion, the figures are 5.7%, 5.7%, 5.6% and 5.2% respectively. All forms of online gambling are licensed by the Gambling Commission and therefore can be legally provided in the country under a licence from the Commission. The Commission's site has details of both licensed operators and applicants. Many bookmakers such as [[888sport]], [[Betfair]], [[Ladbrokes]] and [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill]] have offshore operations but these are largely for overseas customers since no tax is due on winnings of bets in the UK. Before 2001, a 10% levy was paid on bets at an off-course bookmaker (but none at a racecourse) and this could be paid "before" or "after" i.e. on the stake or the winnings, the proceeds going to the [[Horserace Totalisator Board]]. Many would advise you, as a [[tipster]], to "pay the tax before" since it is a smaller amount, but mathematically it works out the same{{clarify|date=August 2016}} since arithmetical [[multiplication]] is [[commutative]]. This tax was abolished with the general reform of the gambling acts. ====Licensed premises (pubs)==== {{see also|Pub games}} Until the Gambling Act 2005, the [[Betting Gaming and Lotteries Act 1963]] prohibited "betting and the passing of betting slips" in licensed premises, that is those licensed to sell alcohol. Six specific games, [[Pool (cue sports)|Pool]], [[Cribbage]], [[Darts]], [[Bar billiards]], [[Shove-halfpenny]] and [[Dominoes]] could be "played for small stakes on those parts of the premises open to the public". A notice to the effect had to be posted in a prominent place. It is legal to place bets via mobile phones from a pub, even through the pub's wi-fi connection, but only for oneself, not for another.{{cite news|publisher=[[Morning Advertiser]]|url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/Business-Support/Legal-checklist-Betting-activity-in-pubs|accessdate=14 March 2014|title=Legal Checklist: Betting activity in pubs|date=18 June 2013|first=Poppleston|last=Allen}} It is also legal for publicans to have pools coupons or other slips available, but not to take the bets themselves. Passing on a bet on behalf of another, in any capacity, is generally considered by law to be acting as an agent and would require a licence. ==Syndicates== [[Betting syndicate]]s, where several bettors pool their bets, may or may not be illegal, depending on the nature of the scheme.{{cite web |url=http://gambling.answers.com/sports-betting/sports-betting-syndicates |work=answers.com |title=Sports betting syndicates |accessdate=12 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904075140/http://gambling.answers.com/sports-betting/sports-betting-syndicates |archivedate=4 September 2014 |df=dmy }} Again, the person actually laying the bet could be considered an agent, especially if they take a cut of the stake. However, [[lottery syndicate]]s are extremely common and even officially encouraged.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} The legal fine point is whether the person collecting the individual stakes and placing the bets is doing so with or without profit (regardless of whether that person is also a member of the syndicate). [[Sweepstake]]s for the [[Grand National]] and occasionally other events are extremely common in offices, and are generally winked at if played for small stakes and not for profit (or that any profit goes to charity). Publicans must also be vigilant in ensuring that their customers do not pass betting slips between each other but only bet for themselves. In general, it is illegal for the holder of a licence to sell alcohol to facilitate betting on the premises.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamblingcommission.gov.uk/pdf/Facilitating%20betting%20in%20pubs%20and%20clubs%20is%20illegal%20-%20February%202008.pdf|work=[[Gambling Commission]]|date=25 August 2010|title=Facilitating betting in pubs is illegal|accessdate=14 March 2014}} Most pubs in the UK have a [[one-armed bandit]] of one kind or another, but the prizes are strictly controlled. The law allows larger prizes in [[private club]]s. ==Economy and taxation== "Betting duty" at 6.75% was applied to sports bets until 2001 when it was replaced by a 15% tax on gross profits.Telegraph https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2736634/Punters-rally-as-betting-tax-ends.html From 1 December 2014, the Gambling (Licensing & Advertising) Bill[http://www.rightcasino.com/news/new-uk-gambling-law-explained/ "New UK gambling law explained: what's all the fuss about?" ''Right Casino''. Retrieved 6 October 2014.] will change the taxation of remote gambling from a 'place of supply' basis to a 'point of consumption' basis.HMRC http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/gamblingtaxreform/index.htm The betting industry alone is reported to contribute £6 billion as of January 2010, 0.5% of [[GDP]]. Furthermore, it employs over 100,000 people and generates £700 Million in tax revenue.{{cite web|url=http://www.egrmagazine.com/news/428923/deloitte-uk-betting-worth-6bn-100000-jobs.thtml/|title=Deloitte: UK betting worth £6bn, 100,000 jobs - EGR Magazine|publisher=}} ==Age restrictions== {{Gambling ages in the United Kingdom}} ==Advertising restrictions== The [[UK government]] previously limited television ads to only National Lottery, Bingo, and football pools, but when a new Gambling Act came into effect in 2007 they relaxed all of those restrictions. By 2013, the UK media regulator [[Ofcom]] reported that this more relaxed approach had led to a six-fold increase in the number of [[gambling]] ads that were aired on the TV.{{cite web|title=UK Gambling Firms Spend Half A Billion in TV Adverts|url=http://grizzlygambling.com/news/uk-gambling-spends-half-a-billion-on-TV-adverts.html|website=GrizzlyG|accessdate=3 August 2016}} ==See also== *[[List of casinos#United Kingdom|List of UK casinos]] *[[Gambling Act 2005|Gambling Act details and updates]] ==Notes== ==External links== *[http://www.gamblingcommission.gov.uk/ UK Gambling Commission] {{Gambling by country}} {{Economy of the United Kingdom}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gambling In The United Kingdom}} [[Category:Gambling in the United Kingdom| ]]

Mohammad Modarres
Peyman Masoudi |writer = [[Arman Arian]] |engine = In-House (build on top of [[OGRE 3D]], [[PhysX]], [[OpenAL]]){{cite web |url=http://www.dasreviews.com/das-game-news/garshasp-the-monster-slayer-is-promising-hack-n-slash-indie-game/ |title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer is a promising hack ‘n’ slash indie game |date=2011-04-22 |publisher=DasReviews |accessdate=2011-05-18}} |released = '''Microsoft Windows'''
May 8, 2011 {{small|(Download)}}
May 31, 2011 {{small|(Retail)}} |genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[hack and slash]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Linux]] }} '''''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer''''' is a [[third-person (video games)|third-person]] [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[video game]] developed by [[Dead Mage Inc.]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Linux]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2011/04/20/behold-garshasp-the-monster-slayer/ |first=Jim |last=Rossignol |title=Behold! Garshasp: The Monster Slayer |date=2011-04-20 |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |accessdate=2011-05-09}} The story and the game are based on the adventures of the mythological Persian monster-slayer [[Garshasp]].{{cite web |url=http://indiegames.com/2011/05/indie_game_pick_garshasp_the_m.html |first=Michael |last=Rose |title=Indie Game Pick: Garshasp: The Monster Slayer (Dead Mage) |date=2011-05-09 |publisher=IndieGames.com |accessdate=2011-05-09}} It was developed by Dead Mage based on an earlier project by the now defunct Fanafzar Sharif Game Studios.{{cite web |url=http://linuxgamingnews.org/2011/05/12/garshap-developers/ |first=Maxim |last=Bardin|title=Garshap Developers |date=2011-05-12 |publisher=Linux Gaming News|accessdate=2011-05-12}} ''Garshasp'' was released for Windows independently online on May 8, 2011, and was released through the [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[GamersGate]] services a day later.{{cite web |url=http://www.pcgamersworld.com/2011/05/garshasp-the-monster-slayer-available-on-steam/ |title=Garshasp The Monster Slayer Available on Steam |date=2011-05-09 |publisher=PCGamersWorld |accessdate=2011-05-10}} Upon release the game received mixed reviews, although it was consistently praised as an ambitious endeavor for an [[independent video game development|independent developer]].{{cite web |url=http://defaultprime.com/2011/05/08/dprime-review-garshasp-the-monster-slayer/ |first=Matt |last=Buckley |title=DPrime Review: Garshasp: The Monster Slayer |date=2011-05-08 |publisher=Default Prime |accessdate=2011-05-09}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/pc/action/garshasp-the-monster-slayer/review.html?tag=summary%3Bread-review |first= Kevin |last=VanOrd |title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer Review for PC |date=2011-05-12 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=2011-05-14}} Dead Mage are currently in the process of porting the game to Linux. == Gameplay == ''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer'' is a [[third-person (video games)|third-person]] [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] game, taking place in mythological ancient Persia, in a world occupied by monsters and [[Deev]]s.{{cite web |url=http://worthplaying.com/article/2011/5/2/news/81174/ |title='Garshasp' Announced - Screens |date=2011-05-02 |publisher=Worthplaying |accessdate=2011-05-10}} The game focuses mainly on combat with large weapons and heavy combo moves. Platforming and puzzle solving also play a major role in the game play style. Garshasp has the ability to jump, double jump, and dodge as well as perform light and heavy attacks. These attacks can be executed in certain orders allowing for several different maneuvers which vary in combat strength and character animation. As the game progresses Garshasp can also accumulate further levels of experience which can further unlock new attacks. The more attacks the player engages in also subsequently raises Garshasp's Rage meter, enabling the player to execute stronger combos. Garshasp can also dispatch weaker enemies through an action resulting in an instant kill, which is useful for dispatching large numbers of enemies. Stronger foes can also be felled in this manner, although they first must be weakened by conventional attacks. Damage to the player may be healed by various blue orbs mounted on pedestals that are scattered throughout the game environment. There are also red orbs that can grant the player experience boosts. The game offers no external control of the camera view, with the game itself programmed to orient the world based on the current action or event taking place. The games puzzle solving element mostly consists of the player opening new areas by hitting switches or levers as well as several environmental challenges, including several scenes where Garshasp must use his sword to assist in a controlled descent down a vertical surface, as well as more traditional platformer elements. == Story == [[File:Personnage principal du jeu-vidéo Garshasp.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Promotional art showing the Main Character]] Years after the confinement of Azhi Dahaka ([[Zahhak]]) by [[Fereydun]] in [[Mount Damavand]], the evil [[Deev]]s who were the commanders in the army of darkness led by Azhi Dahaka rose again in different parts of the ancient lands of Khunirath and rebelled against the humans who were celebrating the victory of the army of light. Each [[Deev]] formed a colony of its own and continued on bringing suffering to the human race. Hitasp, the Golden Crown, who possessed numerous deadly magical skills, was among these [[Deev]]s and was seeking to build up its empire in the rocky lands of Faranbagh in [[Hara Berezaiti]]. Siavoshgard, the legendary village that had been the home of many [[Pahlavan (disambiguation)|Pahlavan]]s{{disambiguation needed|date=March 2017}} was raided by Hitasp and his followers and in the battle, Garshasp’s brother, Oroxia, was killed while defending his ancestral home. Garshasp, the monster slayer and a grand son of [[Jamshid]], starts out pursuing revenge for his brother’s blood by a journey towards the Hitasp's stronghold only to find out that something much more important has been taken in the raid of Siavoshgard and Garshasp’s bravery is to play a big role in the destiny of the world... == Development == Development on the game took place over three years originally by a team of [[Iran]]ian developers under the name of Fanafzar Sharif Game Studios. Fanafzar used mainly [[free software]] tools to develop Garshasp, including the [[OGRE 3D|OGRE]] engine, [[OpenAL]] library, [[Boost C++ Libraries]], and [[WxWidgets]].{{cite web |url=http://linuxgamingnews.org/2009/09/07/interview-with-amir-from-fanafzar-garshasp-developers/ |first=Maxim |last=Bardin|title=Interview With Amir From Fanafzar – Garshasp Developers |date=2009-09-07|publisher=Linux Gaming News|accessdate=2011-05-09}} Development on the game was later moved out of Iran, with the game being completed by the [[Texas|Texan]] studio Dead Mage. The game was unveiled with its new title, ''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer'', in April 2011.{{cite web |url=http://news.bigdownload.com/2011/04/13/garshasp-the-monster-slayer-revealed/ |first=John |last=Callaham|title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer revealed |date=2011-04-13 |publisher=Big Download |accessdate=2011-05-18}} The game was released online for [[Microsoft Windows]] on May 8, 2011 and was made available through the [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[GamersGate]] services on May 9, 2011. The developers are currently porting the game to Linux, and are also considering a port to the [[Xbox Live Arcade]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ogre3d.org/2011/04/29/garshasp-the-monster-slayer| title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer |date=2010-04-29 | publisher=Ogre Website| accessdate=2011-05-07}}{{cite web |url=http://linuxgamingnews.org/2009/08/24/garshasp-action-adventure-game/ |first=Maxim |last=Bardin|title=Garshasp – Action Adventure Game |date=2009-08-24 |publisher=Linux Gaming News|accessdate=2011-05-09}}{{cite web |url=http://linuxgamingnews.org/2010/11/16/garshasp-looking-good/ |first=Maxim |last=Bardin|title=Garshasp – Looking Good |date=2010-11-16 |publisher=Linux Gaming News|accessdate=2011-05-09}} A retail version is going to be made available on May 31, 2011 by the [[Germany|German]] publisher [[Just A Game (publisher)|Just A Game]]. == Reception == {{Video game reviews | state = plain | GR = 53.00%%{{cite web | url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/619213-garshasp-the-monster-slayer/index.html | title=''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer'' for PC | publisher=[[GameRankings]] | accessdate=2011-05-21}} (PC) | MC = 53%{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/garshasp-the-monster-slayer |title=''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer'' (PC): Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=2011-05-19}} (PC) |Destruct = 3.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-garshasp-the-monster-slayer-205958.phtml|title=Review: Garshasp: The Monster Slayer|last=Tan|first=Maurice|publisher=[[Destructoid]]|date=2011-07-13|accessdate=2015-10-09}} | GSpot = 5.0/10 }} ''Garshasp: The Monster Slayer'' received a rating of 6.5/10 from ''Default Prime''. While the reviewer praised it as a competent ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' clone, he thought that the game was too easy and had a few rough edges, stating in conclusion that "imitating a great game does not make a great game". He did however note that it "does succeed in raising the bar on what an independent development studio is capable of delivering." ''[[GameSpot]]'' gave the game a mediocre rating of only 5.0, stating that the game demonstrates "impressive feats for a $19.99 independent release" but also commenting that its "price is attached to a four-hour game that only partially makes good on its potential." ''[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]'' commented that Dead Mage had "obviously worked hard to get the game to this level" and that they "like the way the game is themed and presented", but also complained that it is "the kind of game that ends up looking weak by comparison to its high-budget peers."{{cite web |url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2011/05/10/thoughts-on-garshasp-the-monster-slayer/ |first=Jim |last=Rossignol |title=Thoughts On Garshasp: The Monster Slayer |date=2011-05-10 |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |accessdate=2011-05-10}} ''Player Affinity'' gave the game only a 4.0/10 score, defending the low rating by stating that the game is "an excellent first try from an up-and-coming studio, but it also manages to fall short on several key aspects. These problems, unfortunately, mortally handicap what could have been a moderately enjoyable experience."{{cite web |url=http://playeraffinity.com/pc-reviews/garshasp-the-monster-slayer-review.html |first=Jonathan |last=Gann |title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer Review |date=2011-05-12 |publisher=Player Affinity |accessdate=2011-05-18}} ''ZTGD'' rated the game with a slightly more optimistic 5.5/10 score, mostly complaining about gameplay and performance bugs, but also noted that Dead Mage were working on a patch to hopefully solve some of these issues.{{cite web |url=http://www.ztgd.com/reviews/8856/garshasp-the-monster-slayer/ |first=John |last=Whitehouse |title=Garshasp: The Monster Slayer Review |date=2011-05-18 |publisher=ZTGD |accessdate=2011-05-18}} ''HalfBeard's HUD'' gave the game 3 out of 5 stars, stating that "Garshasp is a more than adequate representation of character action games and while it may not be anything special if you’re a fan of this genre you’ll get some enjoyment out of it.{{cite web |url=http://www.hbhud.com/2011/05/16/review-of-garshasp-the-monster-slayer/ |title=Review of Garshasp: The Monster Slayer|date=2011-05-16 |publisher=HalfBeard's HUD |accessdate=2011-05-19}} ''Digitally Downloaded'' enjoyed the game, but stressed the need for a [[gamepad]] or similar [[video game console|console]] styled controller, saying that it "really deserves to be played on a format that this kind of game was custom built for."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitallydownloaded.net/2011/05/review-garshasp-monster-slayer-very.html |title=Review: Garshasp: The Monster Slayer; a very unfortunate God of War clone (PC) |date=2011-05-11 |publisher=Digitally Downloaded |accessdate=2011-05-14}} ''Mobile Computing News'' decided that the game has "lots of potential, but only provides four hours of fun which can be hindered by some annoying glitches."{{cite web |url=http://www.mobile-computing-news.co.uk/software/11722/review-of-garshasp-the-monster-slayer.html |title=Review of Garshasp: The Monster Slayer |date=2011-05-19 |publisher=Mobile Computing News |accessdate=2011-05-19}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://garshasp.com/ Official Garshasp Website] *[http://deadmage.com/ Official Dead Mage Website] *[http://store.steampowered.com/app/99400/ Garshasp on Steam] *[http://www.gamersgate.com/DD-GMS/garshasp-the-monster-slayer Garshasp on GamersGate] {{DEFAULTSORT:Garshasp (Video Game)}} [[Category:2011 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:Hack and slash games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:Video games based on mythology]] [[Category:Software that uses wxWidgets]] [[Category:Video games developed in Iran]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games set in Iran]]

{{about|the 1953 film|the 1998 television film|Houdini (1998 film)}} {{refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Houdini | image = Houdini.jpg | caption = [[Film poster|Theatrical release poster]] | director = [[George Marshall (director)|George Marshall]] | producer = [[George Pal]]
Berman Swarttz | based on = {{based on|''Houdini''
1928 novel|Harold Kellock}} | writer = [[Philip Yordan]] | starring = [[Tony Curtis]]
[[Janet Leigh]]
[[Torin Thatcher]] | music = [[Roy Webb]] | cinematography = [[Ernest Laszlo]] | editing = [[George Tomasini]] | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1953|7|2}} | runtime = 106 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $1.8 million (US)'The Top Box Office Hits of 1953', ''Variety'', January 13, 1954 }} '''''Houdini''''' is a 1953 American [[Technicolor]] film [[biographical film|biography]] from [[Paramount Pictures]], produced by [[George Pal]] and Berman Swarttz, directed by [[George Marshall (director)|George Marshall]], that stars [[Tony Curtis]] and his then-wife [[Janet Leigh]]. The film's [[screenplay]], based upon the life of magician and escape artist [[Harry Houdini]], is by [[Philip Yordan]], based on the book ''Houdini'' by Harold Kellock. The film's music score was by [[Roy Webb]] and the cinematography by [[Ernest Laszlo]]. The art direction was by [[Albert Nozaki]] and [[Hal Pereira]] and the costume design by [[Edith Head]]. The film's storyline is a fictionalized account of Houdini's life. It details his beginnings as a locksmith, up through his international success as a world-renowned escape artist and stage magician. Following the death of his mother, he exposes various fraudulent Mediums in the [[spiritualism|spiritualist movement]], while always hoping to make contact with her. The film also follows his love for his wife [[Bess Houdini]] and his most dangerous stunts and stage illusions. ==Plot== In the 1890s, young Harry Houdini ([[Tony Curtis]]) is performing with a [[Coney Island]] carnival as Bruto, the Wild Man, when Bess ([[Janet Leigh]]), a naive onlooker, tries to protect him from the blows of Schultz ([[Sig Ruman]]), his "trainer." Harry then appears as magician The Great Houdini and, spotting Bess in the audience, invites her on stage. Harry flirts with the unsuspecting Bess during his act, but she flees from him in a panic. When Bess shows up to watch Harry perform two more times, however, he corners her. Bess admits her attraction, and soon after, the two appear at Harry's mother's house, newly married. Bess becomes Harry's onstage partner, touring the country with him, but soon grows tired of the low pay and grueling schedule. After Bess convinces Harry to take a job in a [[locksmith]] factory, Harry works as a lock tester while fantasizing about escaping from one of the factory's large safes. On [[Halloween]], Harry and Bess attend a special magicians' dinner at the [[Hotel Astor]], during which magician Fante offers a prize to anyone who can free himself from a [[straitjacket]]. Harry accepts the challenge and, through intense concentration, extricates himself from the jacket, greatly impressing Fante. Afterward, however, Fante advises Harry to "drop it," noting that Johann Von Schweger, a [[Germans|German]] magician, retired at the height of his career after performing a similar feat, fearful of his own talents. Bess then persuades Harry to give her his prize, a single, round-trip boat ticket to [[Europe]], so that she can cash it in for a down payment on a house. Later, at the factory, Harry locks himself inside one of the big safes, determined to make an escape. Before he can get out, however, the foreman orders the safe blown open, then fires Harry. That night, in front of his mother (Angela Clarke), Harry and Bess argue about their future, and frustrated by Bess's insistence that he quit magic, Harry walks out. Soon, a contrite Bess finds Harry performing with a [[carnival]] and presents him with two one-way tickets to Europe. Sometime later, at a [[London]] theater, Harry and Bess are concluding their magic act when a reporter named Dooley ([[Michael Pate]]) challenges Harry to break out of one of [[Scotland Yard]]'s notoriously secure jail cells. Harry, who hired Dooley to issue the challenge, accepts the challenge, unaware that the jail's cells do not have locks in the door, but on the outside wall. Despite the added difficulty, the dexterous, determined Houdini picks the cell lock and appears on time for his next performance. Now billed as the "man who escaped from Scotland Yard," Harry begins a successful tour of Europe with Bess. In [[Berlin]], Harry is joined by his mother and begins searching for the reclusive Von Schweger. While performing an impromptu levitation trick with Bess at a restaurant, Harry is arrested for [[fraud]]. During his trial, Harry denies that he ever made claims to [[supernatural powers]], insisting that all his tricks are accomplished through physical means. To prove his point, Harry locks himself in a safe in the courtroom and breaks out a few minutes later, noting that safe locks are designed to keep thieves out, not in. Vindicated, Harry then goes to see Von Schweger, who finally has responded to his queries, but learns from Von Schweger's assistant, Otto ([[Torin Thatcher]]), that the magician died two days earlier. Otto reveals that Von Schweger summoned Harry to ask him the secret of "dematerialization," a feat he accomplished once but could not repeat. Although Harry demurs, Otto insists on becoming Harry's new assistant and travels with him to [[New York City]]. There, Harry finds he is virtually unknown, so for publicity, hangs upside down on a skyscraper flagpole, constrained by a straitjacket. Harry executes the escape and soon makes a name for himself in [[United States|America]]. To prepare to be submerged in a box in the chilly [[Detroit River]], Harry bathes in an ice-filled bathtub. During the trick, which takes place on Halloween, the chain holding the box breaks, and the box drops upside down into an opening in the ice-covered river. Although Harry manages to escape from the box, the current drags him downstream, and he struggles to find air pockets under the ice and swim back to the opening. Above, Bess and the horrified audience assume Harry has drowned and proclaim his demise. To Bess's relief, Harry shows up later at their hotel, saying that he heard his mother's voice, directing him toward the opening. Just then, Harry receives word that his mother died at the exact time that he heard her voice. Two years later in New York, Harry, who has not performed since his mother's death, reveals to Simms ([[Douglas Spencer]]), a reporter, that he has been trying to contact his mother's spirit, without success. Harry invites Simms to attend a seance with him, and after the medium appears to have communicated with his mother, Harry and Otto expose her as a fake. After a public crusade against phony mediums, Harry decides to return to the stage and builds a watery torture cell for the occasion. Terrified, Bess threatens to leave Harry unless he drops the dangerous trick, and he agrees not to perform it. Before the show, Harry admits to Otto that his appendix is tender, but goes on, despite the pain. When the audience noisily demands that he perform the advertised "water torture" trick, Harry succumbs and is immersed, upside down, in a tank of water. Weak, Harry cannot execute the escape and loses consciousness. Otto breaks the tank's glass, and after reviving, the now-dying Harry vows to a weeping Bess that he will come back. ==Cast== {{col div}} * [[Tony Curtis]] as [[Harry Houdini]] * [[Janet Leigh]] as [[Bess Houdini]] * [[Torin Thatcher]] as Otto * [[Angela Clarke (American actress)|Angela Clarke]] as Harry's Mother * [[Stefan Schnabel]] as German Prosecuting Attorney * [[Ian Wolfe]] as Malue * [[Sig Ruman]] as Schultz * [[Michael Pate]] as Dooley * [[Connie Gilchrist]] as Mrs. Shultz * [[Malcolm Lee Beggs]] as British Jail Warden * [[Frank Orth]] as Mr. Hunter * Barry Bernard as Inspector Marlick * [[Douglas Spencer]] as Simms {{col div end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * Hickman, Gail Morgan. ''The Films of George Pal''. South Brunswick, New Jersey: A. S. Barnes and Company, Inc., 1977. {{ISBN|978-0-49801-960-9}}. ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0045886|Houdini}} * {{Allmovie title|23306|Houdini}} * {{tcmdb title|4642|Houdini}} * {{AFI film|id=50876|title=Houdini}} * [http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2010/12/look-back-at-houdini-1953.html A look back at HOUDINI (1953)] at [http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/ Wild About Harry] {{George Marshall}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Houdini}} [[Category:1953 films]] [[Category:1950s biographical films]] [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Roy Webb]] [[Category:Films about magic and magicians]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films directed by George Marshall]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Harry Houdini]]

{{Infobox film | name = I, Tintin | image = Moi,tintin.jpg | image_size = | caption = French VHS cover | director = Henri Roanne & Gérard Valet | producer = | writer = Henri Roanne & Gérard Valet | narrator = | starring = Hergé (Himself), Gérard Valet (Narrator) | music = Alain Pierre | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1976}} | runtime = 51 minutes | country = [[France]]
[[Belgium]] | language = French | budget = }} '''I, Tintin''' ([[French language|French]]: '''''Moi, Tintin''''' ) is a [[France|Franco]]-[[Belgium|Belgian]] film which premiered in the [[Paris]] cinema as a feature presentation in 1975.[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/286074 BFI | Film & TV Database | MOI, TINTIN (1975)][https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0257927/ I, Tintin (1980) - IMDb] Made in [[semidocumentary]] style and mixing interviews with ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'' creator [[Hergé]] with real historical events and news stories edited together with animated ''[[Adventures of Tintin]]'' clips, narrated by Belgian news correspondent, Gérard Valet. The film was produced by [[Belvision Studios]] and Pierre Films in cooperation with the Franco-Belgian Ministry of Culture (Ministère de la Culture Française de Belgique). ==VHS and DVD release== A [[VHS]] was released in French, and it was released on [[DVD]] in 2007 in a double pack with [[Tintin et Moi]], released by Madman Entertainment. It included an interview with Michael Serres, a short film called "The Secret of the Clear Line" and a menu-based Hergé biography. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0257927|title=Moi, Tintin}} {{Tintin and Hergé}} [[Category:1975 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about comics]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Tintin films]] [[Category:Cinema of Belgium]] [[Category:French documentary films]] {{France-documentary-film-stub}} {{Tintin-stub}}

{{short description|album by Bun B}} {{Infobox album | name = II Trill | type = studio | artist = [[Bun B]] | cover = Bun b - ii trill.jpg | alt = | released = May 20, 2008 | recorded = 2007–08 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Southern hip hop]] | length = 60:09 | label = [[Rap-A-Lot Records|Rap-A-Lot]], [[Asylum Records|Asylum]], [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] | producer = Mr. Lee, [[Scott Storch]], [[Jazze Pha]], [[J. R. Rotem]], Bigg Tyme, [[Blackout Movement|BlackOut Movement]], [[DJ Khalil]], [[Clinton Sparks]], Enigma, [[CHOPS]] | prev_title = [[Trill (album)|Trill]] | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = [[Trill OG]] | next_year = 2010 | misc = {{Singles | name = II Trill | type = studio | single1 = [[That's Gangsta]] | single1date = February 19, 2008 | single2 = I'm Damn Cold | single2date = July 31, 2009 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{rating|3.5|5}} {{cite web|last=Jeffries |first=David |url={{Allmusic|class=album |id=r1340226 |pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic review |publisher=Allmusic.com |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2012-08-09}} | rev2 = ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' | rev2Score = {{rating|3|4}} {{cite web|author=JOEY GUERRA, Copyright 2008 Houston Chronicle |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/5790599.html |title=UGK rapper Bun B's latest both cocky and reverent - Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron.com |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2012-02-24}} | rev3 = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | rev3Score = {{rating|3.5|4}} {{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/reviews/music/la-et-recordrack20-2008may20,0,6830758,full.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522185603/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/reviews/music/la-et-recordrack20-2008may20%2C0%2C6830758%2Cfull.story |title=New CDs: Bun B, Flobots, Abigail Washburn, Danielia Cotton |archivedate=2011-05-22 |deadurl=yes |df= }} | rev4 = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | rev4Score = (favorable) {{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/19/arts/music/19choi.html | work=The New York Times | title=New CDs | date=May 19, 2008}} | rev5 = [[Pitchfork Media]] | rev5Score = (7.7/10){{cite web|url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/50949-ii-trill |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114055516/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/50949-ii-trill |archivedate=2009-01-14 |title=II Trill | Pitchfork |publisher=PitchforkMedia.com |date=2009-01-14 |accessdate=2012-08-09}} | rev6 = RapReviews | rev6Score = (9/10)http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2008_05_IItrill.html | rev7 = ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' | rev7Score = {{rating|3.5|5}} {{cite web|url=http://spin-cdnsrc.texterity.com/spin/200806/ |title=The document you are looking for cannot be found |publisher=Spin-cdnsrc.texterity.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-24}} | rev8 = [[UGO]] | rev8Score = (B){{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/ugo/html/article/?id=18588§ionId=2 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615172934/http://www.ugo.com/ugo/html/article/?id=18588§ionId=2 |archivedate=2011-06-15 |title=Bun B - II Trill Album Review | UGO.com |publisher=Ugo.com |date=2011-06-15 |accessdate=2012-08-09}} | rev9 = ''[[The Village Voice]]'' | rev9Score = (favorable){{cite web|author=Evan McGarvey |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/0821,emotionally-fraught-solo-nods-get-paranoid-triumphant,446743,22.html |title=Bun B and Prodigy, On Their Own - Page 1 - Music - New York |publisher=Village Voice |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2012-02-24}} }} '''''II Trill''''' is the second [[studio album]] by [[UGK]] member [[Bun B]]. It was released on May 20, 2008 by [[Rap-a-Lot Records]] and [[Asylum Records]]. The album is the follow-up to his successful debut album, ''[[Trill (album)|Trill]]''. It was mentioned that after the death of his lifelong friend and companion [[Pimp C]], due in part to an accidental overdose, he is likely to "ban the syrup talk on his new CD." The album was originally set to be released on April 29, 2008{{cite web| first=Lauren |last=Carter |title=Bun B Drafts Lil' Wayne & Lupe Fiasco For New LP, Heads Out On Nat'l Tour |url=http://www.sohh.com/articles/article.php/13927 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304013708/http://www.sohh.com/articles/article.php/13927 |archivedate=2008-03-04 |accessdate=2008-03-01 |publisher=SOHH}} but was pushed back to May 20.{{cite web| first= Edwin |last=Ortiz |title=Bun B Talks Obama, Reveals He's Steading Trillin' |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.6712/title.bun-b-talks-obama-reveals-hes-steading-trillin |accessdate=2008-04-08 |publisher=HipHopDX}} The album features lyrics pertaining to political and social issues, as well as a tribute track to Pimp C.{{cite web| first=Rudy |last=West |title=Bun B. Salutes Pimp C.; 'II Trill' On The Way |url=http://allhiphop.com/stories/news/archive/2008/02/01/19225651.aspx |publisher=AllHipHop}} Some of the featured artists on the album, including [[Sean Kingston]], [[Pimp C]], [[Young Buck]], [[Lupe Fiasco]], [[Lil Wayne]], [[David Banner]], [[Rick Ross (rapper)|Rick Ross]], [[Mýa]], [[Chamillionaire]], [[Slim Thug]], [[Webbie]], [[Mike Jones (rapper)|Mike Jones]], [[8Ball & MJG]], [[Z-Ro]], [[Junior Reid]] and [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]].{{cite web| first=Slava |last=Kuperstein |title=Bun B Readies Next Album |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.6471/title.bun-b-readies-next-album |accessdate=2008-03-01 |publisher=HipHopDX}} The [[lead single]], "That's Gangsta" featuring [[Sean Kingston]] was released on May 20, 2008. The second single, "You're Everything" featuring [[Rick Ross (rapper)|Rick Ross]], [[David Banner]], [[8Ball & MJG|8Ball and MJG]] was released on July 31, 2008. Its [[B-Side]] "Pop It 4 Pimp" has also received radio airplay. ''II Trill'' debuted at number two on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, with 98,000 copies sold in the first week of release.{{cite web|last=Ewing |first=Aliya |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.7060/title.hip-hop-album-sales-week-ending-6-1-08 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: Week Ending 6/1/08 | Hip Hop News > |publisher=HipHopDX.com |date=2008-06-04 |accessdate=2012-08-09}}{{cite web|last=Ewing |first=Aliya |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.7101/title.hip-hop-album-sales-week-ending-6-8-08 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: Week Ending 6/8/08 | Hip Hop News > |publisher=HipHopDX.com |date=2008-06-11 |accessdate=2012-08-09}} The album also spent three weeks at the top of the US Rap album chart.{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=bun b|chart=Rap Albums}} |title=Updated Album Charts from the most Trusted Music Magazine |publisher=Billboard |date=2012-08-04 |accessdate=2012-08-09}}{{cite web|last=Hale |first=Andreas |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.7147/title.hip-hop-album-sales-week-ending-6-15-08 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: Week Ending 6/15/08 | Hip Hop News > |publisher=HipHopDX.com |date=2008-06-18 |accessdate=2012-08-09}}{{cite web|last=Ewing |first=Aliya |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.7194/title.hip-hop-album-sales-week-ending-6-22-08 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: Week Ending 6/22/08 | Hip Hop News > |publisher=HipHopDX.com |date=2008-06-25 |accessdate=2012-08-09}}{{cite web|last=Paine |first=Jake |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.7249/title.hip-hop-album-sales-week-ending-6-29-08 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: Week Ending 6/29/08 | Hip Hop News > |publisher=HipHopDX.com |date=2008-07-04 |accessdate=2012-08-09}} The album has since sold 300,000 copies. ==Track listing== {{tracklist | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = II Trill | note1 = featuring [[Z-Ro]] & [[J. Prince]] | extra1 = [[Clinton Sparks]] | length1 = 4:19 | Samples1 = | title2 = [[That's Gangsta]] | note2 = featuring [[Sean Kingston]] | extra2 = [[J. R. Rotem]] | length2 = 3:52 | Samples2 = | title3 = Damn I'm Cold | note3 = featuring [[Lil Wayne]] | extra3 = [[CHOPS]] | length3 = 4:31 | Samples3 = | title4 = [[You're Everything]] | note4 = featuring [[Rick Ross (rapper)|Rick Ross]], [[David Banner]], [[8Ball & MJG]] | extra4 = Mr. Lee | length4 = 4:36 | Samples4 = "[[Cry for You (Jodeci song)|Cry for You]]" by [[Jodeci]] | title5 = I Luv That | note5 = | extra5 = [[Scott Storch]], [[Ron Fair]]* | length5 = 4:02 | Samples5 = | title6 = Swang on 'Em | note6 = featuring [[Lupe Fiasco]] | extra6 = Enigma | length6 = 3:21 | Samples6 = | title7 = My Block | note7 = featuring [[Jazze Pha]] | extra7 = Jazze Pha | length7 = 4:16 | Samples7 = | title8 = Get Cha Issue | note8 = | extra8 = Big Tyme, Qwest, Joshua Moore* | length8 = 4:11 | Samples8 = | title9 = Pop It 4 Pimp | note9 = featuring [[Webbie]] & [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]] | extra9 = Mouse | length9 = 3:50 | Samples9 = "[[Back That Azz Up]]" by [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]] | title10 = Good II Me | note10 = featuring [[Mýa]] | extra10 = Bigg Tyme | length10 = 4:48 | Samples10 = "Just Be Good to Me" by [[S.O.S. Band]] | title11 = Underground Thang | note11 = featuring [[Chamillionaire]] & [[Pimp C]] | extra11 = Cory Mo | length11 = 4:28 | Samples11 = "Steppin' Out" by [[Steel Pulse]] | title12 = If I Die II Night | note12 = featuring [[Lyfe Jennings]] & [[Young Buck]] | extra12 = [[JRock|Jean "JRock" Borges]] | length12 = 4:15 | Samples12 = | title13 = Another Soldier | note13 = featuring [[Mddl Fngz]] & [[Kobe (singer)|Kobe]] | extra13 = [[DJ Khalil]] | length13 = 4:18 | Samples13 = | title14 = If It Was Up II Me | note14 = featuring [[Junior Reid]] | extra14 = [[Blackout Movement|BlackOut Movement]] | length14 = 4:57 | Samples14 = | title15 = Trill Talk | note15 = | extra15 = | length15 = 0:14 | Samples15 = | title16 = Angel in the Sky | note16 = featuring Razah | extra16 = Cozmo, Rodnae | length16 = 4:57 | Samples16 = "Ribbon in the Sky" by [[Stevie Wonder]] | title17 = II Trill Talk | note17 = | extra17 = | length17 = 0:07 | Samples17 = | title18 = Keep It 100 | note18 = | extra18 = CHOPS | length18 = 4:36 | Samples18 = }} {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = [[Best Buy]] bonus tracks | extra_column = Producer(s) | title19 = City of the Swang | extra19 = Cory Mo | note19 = featuring [[Mike Jones (rapper)|Mike Jones]] & [[Slim Thug]] | length19 = 3:58 | Samples19 = | title20 = Some Hoes | extra20 = Big E | note20 = featuring Bulletproof, [[Chino XL]] & [[Killer Mike]] | length20 = 4:49 | Samples20 = }} == Charts == {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! Hiroyuki Kitakubo | music = Marco D'Ambrosio | studio = [[A.P.P.P.]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee | NA = Super Techno Arts }} | first = {{start date|1993|11|19}} | last = {{end date|1994|11|18}} | runtime = 35 minutes (each) | episodes = 6 | episode_list = #Episode list }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = ova | title = Prequel series | director = Hideki Futamura {{small|(chief director)}} | producer = Kazufumi Nomura
Tetsuo Daitoku | writer = Ken'ichi Takashima
Takao Kawaguchi | music = Marco D'Ambrosio | studio = A.P.P.P. | first = {{start date|2000|5|25}} | licensee = {{English anime licensee | NA = Super Techno Arts }} | last = {{end date|2002|10|25}} | runtime = 30 minutes (each) | episodes = 7 | episode_list = #Episode list }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''JoJo's Bizarre Adventure'''''|ジョジョの奇妙な冒険|JoJo no Kimyō na Bōken|lead=yes}} is an [[original video animation]] adaptation of [[Hirohiko Araki]]'s [[manga]] series of the same name, ''[[JoJo's Bizarre Adventure]]''. Produced by [[A.P.P.P.]] (Another Push Pin Planning), it was adapted from the series' third part, ''[[Stardust Crusaders]]''. The first six episodes were originally released by [[Pony Canyon]] on [[VHS]] and [[Laserdisc]] from 1993 to 1994, adapting the latter half of the story arc. This set of episodes begins with Jotaro Kujo and his companions in the middle of their quest to find [[Dio Brando]], offering very little exposition to the back-story that led to the present events of the OVA. The second series, consisting of seven episodes, were released by Klock Worx on [[DVD]] and VHS from 2000 to 2002, featuring most of the same cast, but produced with different directors and writers. These additional episodes, titled "Adventure 1" through "7", served as a [[prequel]] to the earlier-produced episodes, adapting the beginning of the story arc that featured the circumstances that led to Jotaro's quest. The earlier episodes were subsequently re-released as part of this series, but renumbered as "Adventure 8" through "13" to take into account their later chronological placement. A DVD box set featuring all 13 episodes was released on May 25, 2007, which included a soundtrack CD and a set of 31 [[tarot]] cards illustrated by Hirohiko Araki. The series was released in North America by Super Techno Arts. It was released on six DVD volumes 2003 to 2005, dubbed in English, with all 13 episodes also featured in chronological order.[http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2002-04-27/sakura-con-super-techno-arts-panel "Sakura Con - Super Techno Arts Panel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723113126/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2002-04-27/sakura-con-super-techno-arts-panel |date=2011-07-23 }} Retrieved on 2011-09-03. In 2008, distribution for the ''Jojo's Bizarre Adventure'' OVA series was indefinitely suspended following the controversy over the presence of the [[Quran|Qur'an]] in Episode 6. The same story arc would later be adapted for the later ''[[JoJo's Bizarre Adventure (2012 TV series)|JoJo's Bizarre Adventure]]'' TV series in its second season, which aired from 2014 to 2015. ==Episode list== Episodes listed by their English dub titles and in order of their fictional chronology (Series 2 before Series 1, as used in the post-2000 releases of the episodes). {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="80%" ! # ! Title ! Writer ! Release date {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = The Evil Spirit | RTitle = /"Stand" | KanjiTitle = 悪霊 -スタンド- | RomajiTitle = Sutando | WrittenBy = Ken'ichi Takashima | EpisodeNumber = 1 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2000|5|25}}{{cite web |title=ジョジョの奇妙な冒険(2000) |url=http://www.allcinema.net/prog/show_c.php?num_c=159860#7 |website=allcinema |language=Japanese}} | ShortSummary = Seventeen-year-old [[Jotaro Kujo]] refuses to leave his jail cell, believing that he is possessed by an evil spirit. When Jotaro's mother, Holly, his grandfather [[Joseph Joestar]], and the mysterious [[Mohammed Avdol]] come to try to coax him out, a battle erupts between Avdol's "evil spirit" Magician's Red and Jotaro's Star Platinum, revealed to be psychic manifestations known as Stands. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = Hierophant Green | KanjiTitle = 法皇の緑 -ハイエロファントグリーン- | RomajiTitle = Haierofanto Gurīn | WrittenBy = Ken'ichi Takashima | EpisodeNumber = 2 | OriginalAirDate ={{Start date|2000|8|25}} | ShortSummary = Jotaro learns the secret of his Stand power and about his family's enemy, the vampire [[Dio Brando|DIO]]. Later, Jotaro is attacked by [[Noriaki Kakyoin]] and his Stand Hierophant Green, an assassin controlled by DIO. When Holly falls into a Stand-induced coma, Joseph, Jotaro, and the others embark on a dangerous journey to Egypt to save her life and end the 100-year battle between DIO and the Joestar family. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = Silver Chariot and Strength | KanjiTitle = 銀の戦車＆力 -シルバーチャリオッツ＆ストレングス- | RomajiTitle = Shirubā Chariottsu to Sutorengusu | WrittenBy = Ken'ichi Takashima | EpisodeNumber = 3 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2000|10|27}} | ShortSummary = When the private jet carrying Jotaro and his companions to Egypt suddenly bursts into flames, the plane is forced to land in the ocean. As the party drifts in a lifeboat, a large freighter pulls alongside and they climb aboard. To their shock, there is no crew to be found—and the only passengers left aboard are an orangutan and enemy Stand user [[Jean-Pierre Polnareff]], user of Silver Chariot. However, Polnareff is another one of DIO's unwilling victims, and soon joins the group as they face off against the orangutan Forever and his Stand Strength. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = The Emperor and the Hanged Man | KanjiTitle = 皇帝と吊られた男 -エンペラーとハングドマン- | RomajiTitle = Enperā to Hangudoman | WrittenBy = Takao Kawaguchi | EpisodeNumber = 4 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2001|4|27}} | ShortSummary = At a stopover on the way to Egypt, Polnareff is attacked by the Stand known as the Hanged Man, an enemy Stand who has two right hands and can only be seen in reflections. Realizing that it must be controlled by the same Stand user that had killed his younger sister, Polnareff breaks away from the rest of the group to seek his revenge. Polnareff is lured into a trap set by J. Geil, user of the Hanged Man and his partner, Hol Horse. When some of the party come to his aid, Avdol is killed by Hol Horse's Stand the Emperor. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = The Judgement | KanjiTitle = 裁き -Sanction- | RomajiTitle = Sabaki | WrittenBy = Takao Kawaguchi | EpisodeNumber = 5 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2001|6|29}} | ShortSummary = Kakyoin and Polnareff desperately seek a way to defeat the Hanged Man, who can strike out at them from within reflections while remaining invulnerable to their attacks. They must figure out a way to fight a Stand that can move at nearly the speed of light and can attack from anywhere. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = The Mist of Vengeance | KanjiTitle = 報復の霧 -Vengeance- | RomajiTitle = Hōfuku no Kiri | WrittenBy = Takao Kawaguchi | EpisodeNumber = 6 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2001|9|28}} | ShortSummary = A thick fog envelopes the group as they travel towards Egypt, so they seek refuge in a nearby town. There, the companions stumble across a strangely mutilated dead body lying on a street corner. An old woman arrives on the scene with the police, and offers to let them stay at her hotel for the night. In the hotel bar, Polnareff encounters Enya, a beautiful and mysterious young woman on a deadly quest of revenge of her own as Polnareff has killed her son J. Geil. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = Justice | KanjiTitle = 正義 -ジャスティス- | RomajiTitle = Jasutisu | WrittenBy = Takao Kawaguchi | EpisodeNumber = 7 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2002|1|25}} | ShortSummary = Polnareff becomes a living puppet under the control of Enya and her incredible mist of death Stand Justice. The group battles its way out of the hotel, only to find themselves surrounded by legions of the dead. All seems lost when Jotaro falls prey to a bizarre sneak attack, leaving him vulnerable to Enya's control as well. However, he soon comes up with a way to reveal the true identity of their foe. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = Iggy the Fool and N'Doul the GEB (Pt. I) | KanjiTitle = 「愚者」のイギーと「ゲブ神」のンドゥール -前編- | RomajiTitle = "Za Fūru" no Igī to "Gebu-shin" no Ndūru -Zenpen- | WrittenBy = Hiroyuki Kitakubo | EpisodeNumber = 8 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1993|11|21}}{{cite web |title=ジョジョの奇妙な冒険 |url=https://mediaarts-db.bunka.go.jp/an/anime_series/4629?display_view=pc |website=Media Arts DataBase |publisher=Agency for Cultural Affairs}} | ShortSummary = Jotaro and his companions finally reach Egypt. There, they are met by a Speedwagon Foundation helicopter that delivers a new addition to their group—a dog named Iggy who is actually the user of The Fool Stand. When the helicopter crashes just a short time later, the group investigates, only to find themselves pitted against another of DIO's assassins—N'Doul and his deadly Stand, the Egyptian god Geb. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = Iggy the Fool and N'Doul the GEB (Pt. II) | KanjiTitle = 「愚者」のイギーと「ゲブ神」のンドゥール -後編- | RomajiTitle = "Za Fūru" no Igī to "Gebu-shin" no Ndūru -Kōhen- | WrittenBy = Hiroyuki Kitakubo | EpisodeNumber = 9 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1993|12|17}} | ShortSummary = Jotaro and the others find themselves stranded and at the mercy of N'Doul's incredibly strong and mercurial Stand Geb. Faced with almost certain death, Jotaro makes a desperate gambit and forces Iggy to help him strike back at N'Doul, but Iggy has other plans. He betrays Jotaro at a critical moment, offering him to Geb in order to save his own life. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = D'Arby the Gambler | KanjiTitle = ダービー・ザ・ギャンブラー | RomajiTitle = Dābī Za Gyanburā | WrittenBy = Hiroyuki Kitakubo | EpisodeNumber = 10 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|8|9}} | ShortSummary = The companions search the huge Egyptian capital of Cairo, showing everyone they meet the photo of a mysterious building where they think DIO resides. In an odd café, they encounter a gambler named D'Arby who claims to have the information they need. The catch is, they have to beat him in the ultimate wager—one where their very souls are at stake thanks to the use of his Stand Osiris. After Polnareff and Joseph fall victim to D'Arby's cheats, Jotaro must come up with a way to out gamble a gambler. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = DIO's World: The Warrior of the Void: Vanilla Ice | KanjiTitle = DIOの世界 -亜空の瘴気ヴァニラ・アイス- | RomajiTitle = DIO no Sekai -Akū no Shōki Vanira Aisu- | WrittenBy = Satoshi Kon | EpisodeNumber = 11 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|7|21}} | ShortSummary = Jotaro and his companions finally arrive at DIO's lair and find their way to the room where his coffin resides. Just as they prepare to strike the fatal blow, DIO's mysterious Stand powers, coupled with that of his finest assassin, Vanilla Ice, slay Avdol before their horrified eyes. Jotaro, Joseph, and Kakyoin go after DIO, hoping to kill him before the sun sets when he will have free rein over the city, while Polnareff and Iggy get revenge for Avdol's death against Vanilla Ice. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = DIO's World: Kakyoin - Duel in the Barrier | KanjiTitle = DIOの世界 -花京院 結界の死闘- | RomajiTitle = DIO no Sekai -Kakyōin: Kekkai no Shitō- | WrittenBy = Satoshi Kon | EpisodeNumber = 12 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|10|21}} | ShortSummary = DIO pursues Joseph through the streets of Cairo, leaving an incredible swath of death and destruction in his wake. Kakyoin comes to Joseph's aid, only to be crushed by the power of DIO's Stand The World. As Kakyoin lies alone and dying, he realizes in the last moments of life the true nature of DIO's Stand, and he attempts to send them one final message to reveal that The World can stop time. }} {{Japanese episode list | EnglishTitle = DIO's World: Farewell, My Friends | KanjiTitle = DIOの世界 -さらば友よ- | RomajiTitle = DIO no Sekai -Saraba Tomo yo- | WrittenBy = Satoshi Kon | EpisodeNumber = 13 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|11|18}} | ShortSummary = The century-old blood feud finally comes to a close in the final battle between Jotaro and DIO. The World seems invincible as Jotaro is struck time and time again with murderous blows. If Jotaro cannot discover the secret of DIO's Stand and find some way to counter it, the Joestar line will come to an abrupt and bloody end. }} |} ==Controversy== In May 2008, both studio A.P.P.P. and Shueisha halted OVA/manga shipments of ''JoJo's Bizarre Adventure'' after a complaint had been launched against them from [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] [[Islamic fundamentalism|Islamic fundamentalists]], after noticing a scene in the OVAs that has the villain, Dio Brando, reading a book depicting pages from the [[Quran|Qur'an]].{{cite web |title=Jason Thompson's House of 1000 Manga - Jojo's Bizarre Adventure |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/house-of-1000-manga/2010-12-23 |work=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=2012-12-29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422183157/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/house-of-1000-manga/2010-12-23 |archivedate=2012-04-22 |df= }}{{cite web |title=Jojo's Anime, Manga Sales Halted Due to Islamic Images |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-05-22/jojo-anime-manga-sales-halted-due-to-islamic-images |work=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=2012-12-29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524170858/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-05-22/jojo-anime-manga-sales-halted-due-to-islamic-images |archivedate=2008-05-24 |df= }} This recall affected the English-language release of the manga as well, causing Viz Media and Shueisha to cease publication for a year. Even though the manga did not feature that specific scene, Shueisha had Araki redraw scenes that depicted characters fighting on top of, and destroying, [[mosque]]s. Viz resumed publication a year later, with the eleventh volume being published on April 7, 2009. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{ann|OVA|463|JoJo's Bizarre Adventure}} {{JoJo's Bizarre Adventure}} {{A.P.P.P.}} [[Category:JoJo's Bizarre Adventure|OVAs]] [[Category:1993 anime OVAs]] [[Category:2000 anime OVAs]] [[Category:Cartoon controversies]] [[Category:Television articles with incorrect naming style]]

{{For|the TV series|Legion of Super Heroes (TV series)}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=May 2013}} {{Original research|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox comics organization |name = Legion of Super-Heroes |image = Legion of Super-Heroes (Post-Infinite Crisis).png |imagesize = 250 |caption = {{Descript-cvr-art|Legion of Super-Heroes|6|9|March, 2011|art=Yildiray Cinar|pub=DC}} |publisher = [[DC Comics]] |debut = ''[[Adventure Comics]]'' #247 |debutmo = April |debutyr = 1958 |debuthead = Original |debut1 = ''Legion of Super-Heroes'' vol. 4 #0 |debutmo1 = October |debutyr1 = 1994 |debuthead1 = Reboot |debut2 = ''Teen Titans/Legion Special'' |debutmo2 = November |debutyr2 = 2004 |debuthead2 = Threeboot |debut3 = ''[[Justice League|Justice League of America]]'' vol. 2 #8 |debutmo3 = April |debutyr3 = 2007 |debuthead3 = Post-Infinite Crisis |creators = [[Otto Binder]] (writer)
[[Al Plastino]] (artist) |type = |business = |organisation = |organization = |team = |base = Legion Clubhouse
Legion Outpost
Legion World |owners = |employees = |members = |fullroster = ''[[List of Legion of Super-Heroes members]]'' |cat = teams |subcat = DC Comics |altcat = |hero = y |villain = |sortkey = Legion of Super-Heroes }} The '''Legion of Super-Heroes''' is a fictional [[superhero]] team appearing in American comic books published by [[DC Comics]]. Created by writer [[Otto Binder]] and artist [[Al Plastino]], the Legion is a group of superpowered beings living in the 30th and 31st centuries of the {{DC Universe}}, and first appears in ''[[Adventure Comics]]'' #247 (April 1958). Initially, the team was closely associated with the original [[Superboy (Kal-El)|Superboy]] character ([[Superman]] when he was a teenager), and was portrayed as a group of [[time travel]]ers. Later, the Legion's origin and back story were fleshed out, and the group was given its own monthly comic. Eventually, Superboy was removed from the team altogether and appeared only as an occasional guest star. The team has undergone two major [[reboot (fiction)|reboots]] during its run. The [[Legion of Super-Heroes (1958 team)|original version]] was replaced with a [[Legion of Super-Heroes (1994 team)|new rebooted version]] following the events of the "[[Zero Hour: Crisis in Time|Zero Hour]]" storyline in 1994 and [[Legion of Super-Heroes (2004 team)|another rebooted team]] was introduced in 2004. A [[Legion of Super-Heroes (1958 team)#Post-Infinite Crisis (2007–2015)|fourth version of the team]], nearly identical to the original version, was introduced in 2007. ==Publication history== ===Original continuity (1958–1994)=== {{main|Legion of Super-Heroes (1958 team)}} [[Image:Adv247legion.jpg|thumb|The cover of ''Adventure Comics'' #247 (April 1958), the Legion's first appearance. Art by [[Curt Swan]] and Stan Kaye.]] [[Superboy (Kal-El)|Superboy]] was the featured series in ''[[Adventure Comics]]'' in the 1950s. In ''Adventure Comics'' #247 (April 1958) by writer [[Otto Binder]] and artist [[Al Plastino]], Superboy was met by three teenagers from the 30th century: [[Garth Ranzz|Lightning Boy]], [[Saturn Girl]], and [[Cosmic Boy]], who were members of a "super-hero club" called the Legion of Super-Heroes.{{cite book|last=Irvine|first= Alex|authorlink = Alexander C. Irvine|last2=Dolan|first2=Hannah, ed.|chapter= 1950s|title = DC Comics Year By Year A Visual Chronicle|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|year=2010|location= London, United Kingdom|isbn= 978-0-7566-6742-9 |page= 89 |quote = The Legion of Super-Heroes would become one of DC's most enduring and popular groups despite their humble beginnings, in a story by writer Otto Binder and artist Al Plastino}} Their club had been formed with Superboy as an inspiration, and they had [[time travel]]led to recruit Superboy as a member. After a series of tests, Superboy was awarded membership and returned to his own time. Although intended as a one-off story focusing on Superboy, the Legion proved so popular that it returned for an encore in ''Adventure Comics'' #267 (December 1959). In this story, Lightning Boy had been renamed [[Lightning Lad]], and their costumes were very close to those they wore throughout the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]]. The Legion's popularity grew, and they appeared in further stories in ''Adventure Comics'', ''[[Action Comics]]'', and other titles edited by [[Mort Weisinger]] over the next few years.{{gcdb|type=editor|search= Mort+Weisinger|title= Mort Weisinger (editor)}} The ranks of the Legion, only hinted at in those first two stories, was filled with new heroes such as [[Chameleon Boy]], [[Invisible Kid]], [[Colossal Boy]], [[Star Boy]], [[Brainiac 5]], [[Luornu Durgo|Triplicate Girl]], [[Shrinking Violet (comics)|Shrinking Violet]], [[Sun Boy]], [[Bouncing Boy]], [[Phantom Girl]], and [[Ultra Boy]]. Even the 20th-century cousin to Superman, [[Supergirl (Kara Zor-El)|Supergirl]], was recruited as a member.{{cite comic| Writer = [[Jerry Siegel|Siegel, Jerry]]| Penciller = [[Jim Mooney|Mooney, Jim]]| Inker = Mooney, Jim| Story = Supergirl's Three Super Girl-Friends!| Title = Action Comics | Issue = 276 | date = May 1961}} In ''Adventure Comics'' #300 (September 1962), the Legion received their own regular feature, cover-billed "Superboy in 'Tales of the Legion of Super-Heroes'".{{cite comic| writer= Siegel, Jerry| penciller= [[John Forte|Forte, John]]| inker= Forte, John| story= The Face Behind the Lead Mask!| title= Adventure Comics| issue= 300| date= September 1962}} While they would share space with Superboy solo stories for a couple of years, they eventually displaced Superboy from the title entirely as their popularity grew. Lightning Lad was killed in ''Adventure Comics'' #304 (January 1963) and revived in issue #312 (September 1963).McAvennie, Michael "1960s" in Dolan, p. 108: "The demise of the Legion co-founder was a first not only for the Legion fan base, but for mainstream comics in general...Lightning Lad was resurrected later that year in ''Adventure Comics'' #312." It was the ''Adventure Comics'' run which established the Legion's general workings and environment.{{cite journal|last = Kingman|first = Jim|title = Move Over, Superboy! (And Tell Legion Fandom the News!) The Resurgence of the Legion of Super-Heroes During the Bronze Age of Comics|journal = [[Back Issue!]]|issue = 68|page = 3|publisher = [[TwoMorrows Publishing]]|date = October 2013|location= Raleigh, North Carolina}} A club of teenagers, they operated out of a clubhouse in the shape of an inverted yellow [[Spacecraft|rocket ship]] which looked as if it had been driven into the ground. The position of Legion leader rotated among the membership. Each Legionnaire had to possess one natural superpower which no other member possessed; despite this, several members had overlapping powers, particularly Superboy, Supergirl, [[Lar Gand|Mon-El]], and Ultra Boy. Some issues included comical moments where candidates with bizarre, useless, or dangerous abilities would try out for membership and be rejected; five of these flawed candidates went on to form the [[Legion of Substitute Heroes]]. The Legion was based on Earth and protected an organization of humans and aliens called the [[United Planets]] alongside the regular police the [[Science Police]]. The setting for each story was 1000 years from the date of publication. In ''Adventure Comics'' #346 (July 1966), [[Jim Shooter]], 14 years old at the time, wrote his first Legion story.McAvennie "1960s" in Dolan, p. 118: "In his first-ever published story, fourteen-year-old Jim Shooter admitted four new members into the Legion of Super-Heroes ... Shooter's long, memorable tenure as one of the Legion's greatest writers was officially underway." Soon thereafter, Shooter became the regular writer of the Legion stories, with Curt Swan, and later [[Win Mortimer]], as artist. Shooter wrote the story in which [[Ferro Lad]] died—the first "real" death of a Legionnaire (although Lightning Lad had been believed dead for a while before)—and introduced many other enduring concepts, including the [[Fatal Five]],McAvennie "1960s" in Dolan, p. 123: "Writer Jim Shooter and artist Curt Swan unleashed an even greater menace when the Fatal Five decided to stay united in the years ahead." [[Karate Kid (comics)|Karate Kid]], [[Princess Projectra]], [[Shadow Lass]], the [[Dark Circle]], [[Mordru]] and the "Adult Legion", a conjecture regarding what the Legionnaires would be like when they grew up. The Legion's last appearance in ''Adventure Comics'' was #380 (May 1969),{{cite comic| writer= [[Jim Shooter|Shooter, Jim]]| penciller= [[Win Mortimer|Mortimer, Win]]| inker= [[Jack Abel|Abel, Jack]]| story= The Legion's Space Odyssey| title= Adventure Comics| issue= 380| date= May 1969}} and they were displaced by Supergirl in the next issue. The early 1970s saw the Legion relegated to the status of back-up feature. First, the team's stories were moved to ''Action Comics'' for issues #377–392 (June 1969 – September 1970). Following Mort Weisinger's retirement from DC, the Legion was passed to the oversight of editor [[Murray Boltinoff]] and began appearing occasionally as a backup in ''Superboy'', starting with #172 (March 1971),{{gcdb|type=editor|search= Murray+Boltinoff|title= Murray Boltinoff (editor)}} with writers [[E. Nelson Bridwell]] and [[Cary Bates]] and artist [[George Tuska]]. [[Dave Cockrum]] began drawing the series with ''Superboy'' #184 (April 1972), again increasing the team's popularity.McAvennie "1970s" in Dolan, p. 151: "After more than a year as Murphy Anderson's background inker, Dave Cockrum landed his big DC break as the ''Legion of Super-Heroes'' artist ... Cockrum's debut story, which was written by Cary Bates, quickly established an exciting new vibe for the super-team." ====''Superboy'' and their own title==== [[File:Legion of Super-Heroes (Silver Age version).jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Legion of Super-Heroes as seen in the ''1976 DC Calendar''. Art by [[Neal Adams]] and [[Dick Giordano]].]] The first comic book published under the title ''Legion of Super-Heroes'' was a four-issue series published in 1973 that reprinted Legion tales from ''Adventure Comics''.{{cite journal|last=Kingman|first=Jim|title=Reprint Madness: DC's Short-Lived Reprint Line of 1972–1973|journal=Back Issue!|issue=81|pages=47–52|publisher=TwoMorrows Publishing|date=July 2015|location= Raleigh, North Carolina}}{{gcdb series|id= 2099|title=Legion of Super-Heroes}} In the same year, the Legion returned to cover billing on a book when ''Superboy'' became ''Superboy starring the Legion of Super-Heroes'' with #197 (August 1973). Crafted by Bates and Cockrum, the feature proved popular and saw such events as the wedding of Bouncing Boy and [[Luornu Durgo|Duo Damsel]] in ''Superboy'' #200 (Feb 1974).McAvennie "1970s" in Dolan, p. 159: "Bouncing Boy and Duo Damsel became the first Legionnaires to tie the knot. The wedding planners were writer Cary Bates and artist Dave Cockrum."
